item.title: Trump Orders Blockade of Some Oil Tankers to and From Venezuela
item.description: The move is an escalation of military operations and a pressure campaign against Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s leader. But its scope and economic impact are not clear.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Simon Romero, Charlie Savage and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil tankers anchored in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2021. Venezuela relies entirely on tankers to export its oil to world markets.

item.title: Team Races Against Time to Save a Tangled Sea Lion in British Columbia
item.description: Experts tracked the sea lion, which had a rope around its neck, for over a month before they were able to catch up to it in Cowichan Bay, Canada.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.category: Vancouver Aquarium Marine Mammal Rescue Society

item.title: Penguins Become Prey for the Pumas of Patagonia
item.description: In Argentina, the return of pumas brought top predators back to the landscape — much to penguins’ dismay.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

item.title: When the Bones Were Good, These Bees Buried Their Babies
item.description: A cave in the Dominican Republic concealed thousands of years worth of animal bones that had been turned into nests by prehistoric bees.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea

item.title: US Boat Strikes Shift to Pacific, Placing Colombia on Watch
item.description: All the strikes in recent weeks have taken place in the Pacific, reflecting Colombia’s role in the drug trade and the feuding between Bogotá and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: Video images posted by the U.S. Southern Command on Monday showed what the U.S. military said were strikes on three narcotrafficking vessels in the eastern Pacific Ocean.

item.title: Hegseth Declines to Show Lawmakers Boat Strike Video
item.description: The defense secretary joined the secretary of state on Capitol Hill to deliver the first classified briefings to include all members of the House and Senate on the maritime attacks.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth briefed lawmakers on Tuesday on the military’s strikes on boats in international waters.

item.title: Mark Carney Caught in Canada’s British Spelling Debate
item.description: Some words spelled the British way are emerging in Canadian government documents. A group of language experts say the changes undermine Canada’s identity.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Justin Tang/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada speaking in Ottawa last week. As a former leader of England’s central bank Mr. Carney spent years exposed to British English.

item.title: U.S. Sends Cubans to Naval Station at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: The transfer of nearly two dozen men this week restarted a Trump administration deportation operation on the base after a two-month hiatus.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: About 730 men have been held at the base by Immigration and Customs Enforcement, including this week’s arrivals.

item.title: Trinidad and Tobago Sides With U.S. in Battle Against Venezuela, Military Tool Suggests
item.description: The United States and Trinidad say U.S. Marines installed a radar in Tobago to combat drugs — but this war materiel isn’t designed for operations based at sea or on land.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:description: A U.S. radar at the A.N.R. Robinson International Airport in Trinidad and Tobago.

item.title: Venezuela’s Oil Is a Focus of Trump’s Campaign Against Maduro
item.description: In public, the White House says it is confronting Venezuela to curb drug trafficking. Behind the scenes, gaining access to the country’s vast oil reserves is a priority.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil drilling equipment in Cabimas, Venezuela. The country has about 17 percent of the world’s known oil reserves, nearly four times the amount in the United States.

item.title: U.S. Strikes 3 More Boats in Eastern Pacific, Killing 8
item.description: The attacks brought the number killed since the Trump administration began the strikes on suspected drug smugglers to at least 95.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Willis
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An image taken from video released on Monday by the U.S. Southern Command.

item.title: ‘Titaníque,’ Singing and Spoofing Celine Dion, Sets Sail for Broadway
item.description: This zany musical made it from the basement of a Manhattan grocery to London’s West End, and now hopes to become Broadway’s next hit comedy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Evelyn Freja for The New York Times
item.media:description: The “Titaníque” team includes, from top to bottom, the director Tye Blue, the writer Constantine Rousouli, the actor Marla Mindelle and the music supervisor Nicholas James Connell.

item.title: Kast’s Victory in Chile Is Another Win for Global Right-Wing Movement
item.description: José Antonio Kast, who was elected president on Sunday, is the latest conservative to rise to power promising strict law and order measures.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: José Antonio Kast and his wife, Maria Pia Adriazola, celebrating on Sunday in Santiago, Chile, after the runoff election.

item.title: U.S. Military Plane and JetBlue Flight Nearly Collided Over Caribbean, Radio Traffic Shows
item.description: The Air Force refueling tanker was flying without its location transponder activated and could not be detected by air traffic control.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A U.S. Air Force air-to-air refueling tanker took off from an airport in St. Croix in late November. A similar type of aircraft nearly collided with a JetBlue flight on Friday over the Caribbean, according to air traffic control radio communications.

item.title: José Antonio Kast Elected President of Chile
item.description: José Antonio Kast has promised to reverse Chile’s recent surge in violent crime. He also says he will deport undocumented migrants.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: José Antonio Kast with supporters after voting in Paine, Chile, on Sunday.

item.title: Reporting on Arctic Sovereignty in the Polar Bear Capital of the World
item.description: Global competition in the Arctic is raising hopes of a revival in the town of Churchill. We went to meet the people, and the bears, there.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Known in recent years mostly for its polar bears, there are now efforts to revive infrastructure in Churchill, Manitoba.

item.title: Chile Poised for Right-Wing Victory as Crime Fears Sweep Latin America
item.description: Security has become a top concern for voters across the region who are calling for iron-fisted measures. In Chile, the issue is pushing the country to the right.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Sara Wayra
item.media:credit: Sara Wayra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chilean police raiding a house in Iquique during an anti-gang operation last month.

item.title: Venezuela Oil Tanker Seized by U.S. Was Part of Effort to Finance Cuba
item.description: Firms with ties to Cuba are getting a larger share of Venezuelan oil exports, as the island’s security agents boost President Nicolás Maduro’s defenses.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Nicholas Nehamas and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: An oil tanker called the Skipper in the southern Caribbean Sea. It was seized by the United States.

item.title: To Get to Oslo, Machado Skirted Military Checkpoints and Survived Rough Seas
item.description: An American firm with experience in special operations spirited María Corina Machado, the recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize, out of the country in a secretive land, sea and air operation.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Simon Romero
item.media:description: María Corina Machado spent the last year hiding from President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela’s regime.

item.title: U.S. Lifts Sanctions Against Justice Alexandre de Moraes of Brazil
item.description: A senior Trump administration official said that maintaining sanctions against Justice Alexandre de Moraes was no longer in the interest of the United States.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Alexandre de Moraes reading the charges against former President Jair Bolsonaro during the opening session of the trial in Brazil in September.

item.title: For Rubio the Cuba Hawk, the Road to Havana Runs Through Venezuela
item.description: President Trump’s secretary of state and national security adviser has long sought to cripple or topple Cuba’s government, which has close security and economic ties to Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s parents immigrated to Florida from Havana three years before Cuba’s communist revolution prevailed in 1959.

item.title: Canadians Rush to Buy Stockpiles of Boycotted U.S. Liquor
item.description: Four Canadian provinces are selling off the American liquor they pulled from shelves in protest over President Trump’s tariffs. Some bourbon drinkers are thrilled.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: American alcohol products were removed from store shelves in much of Canada when U.S. tariffs against the country went into effect in March.

item.title: A Seized Oil Tanker Off Venezuela and the Big Business of Dark Fleet Smuggling
item.description: The U.S. seizure of a vessel off Venezuela is likely to squeeze the country’s government, but do little to counter the tankers that secretively move oil from sanctioned countries.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil tankers anchored at a refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2022. The country relies heavily on a so-called dark fleet to export its oil.

item.title: ‘Storm Highway’ Forecast to Send More Rain to Washington and British Columbia
item.description: Just as this week’s floodwaters in the Pacific Northwest begin to recede, forecasters warn, another storm will approach the West Coast.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff

item.title: U.S. Issues New Sanctions Targeting Maduro’s Family and the Oil Sector
item.description: The United States is escalating its pressure campaign on Venezuela’s leader, Nicolás Maduro, after seizing an oil tanker off the coast.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Tyler Pager, Farnaz Fassihi and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro during a rally in Caracas on Wednesday.

item.title: What to Know About Trump’s Seizure of an Oil Tanker Near Venezuela
item.description: The tanker was headed eastward and had recently carried Iranian oil. The seizure is an escalation in President Trump’s military pressure campaign against Venezuela’s leader, Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Nicholas Nehamas
item.media:description: A satellite image showing the Skipper, an oil tanker, near Port Jose, Venezuela, in November.

item.title: What Does the Oil Tanker Seizure Mean for Venezuela’s Economy?
item.description: Seizures of more tankers could put a stranglehold on Venezuela’s economy, which is exceptionally dependent on oil to keep the government running and pay for basic necessities.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil tanker docked at Cardon Refinery in Venezuela, in 2021.

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize Winner Machado Says U.S. Helped Her Leave Venezuela
item.description: María Corina Machado reappeared on the global stage as the Trump administration ramped up its pressure campaign against President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:description: María Corina Machado at a news conference in Oslo, Norway, on Thursday after spending more than a year in hiding.

item.title: British Columbia Flooding Forces Hundreds to Evacuate
item.description: The atmospheric river over the Pacific Northwest brought a deluge to British Columbia, forcing road closures and evacuations in Canada.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: A closed road in Fraser Valley, British Columbia.

item.title: Mexico Approves 50% Tariffs on Many Chinese Imports
item.description: The tariffs will apply to goods from China and other nations. Washington has been pressuring Mexico to move away from dealing with China.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and James Wagner
item.media:description: A display of cars by the Chinese automaker BYD in the Mexican city of Ciudad Juarez. China is the second largest exporter to Mexico after the United States.

item.title: María Corina Machado Appears in Norway After Missing Nobel Ceremony
item.description: María Corina Machado, who spent over a year in hiding in Venezuela, greeted supporters in Oslo, hours after her daughter accepted the Nobel Peace Prize in her name.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Jonas Been Henriksen/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: María Corina Machado greeting supporters in Oslo from a hotel balcony early on Thursday morning.

item.title: Lawsuit Challenges Park Service Passes Featuring Trump
item.description: An environmental group is suing, saying federal law requires an image of public lands, not the president.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Seized Oil Tanker Off Venezuelan Coast
item.description: The seizure comes as the United States builds up its forces in the Caribbean as part of a campaign against President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Eric Schmitt and Nicholas Nehamas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump announced the seizure at the White House on Wednesday, without giving details on the operation.

item.title: Venezuela’s Nobel Peace Prize Winner Raises Stakes in Stand off With Maduro
item.description: The decision by María Corina Machado, the Venezuelan opposition leader, to emerge from hiding and leave the country has electrified her movement but carries political risks.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Henrik Pryser Libell and Simon Romero
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ana Corina Sosa, the daughter of the Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado, speaking at the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony on Wednesday in Oslo.
